awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Theoretical Investigation of Photo-induced Charge and Energy Transfer in Organic Photovoltaic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nandini Ananth of Cornell University is supported by a CAREER award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop new theoretical methods to uncover a detailed, atomistic-level picture of the factors that drive efficient electron and energy transport in material systems. A delicate balance of chemical interactions along with external forces like light and heat determine the outcomes of reactions in complex molecular systems. The current research focuses on designing organic solar cell materials that absorb solar photons and efficiently generate free electrons. The long-term objectives of this research are to develop a complete toolbox of theoretical methods that can provide general, transferable design principles for materials relevant to renewable energy technology. 

The use of mathematical tools to understand chemical reactions is central to the proposed work, and is reflected in the educational outreach component of this award. The early incorporation of mathematics significantly impacts aptitude for science in the later stages of education and is an important step towards encouraging participation in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) careers. This challenge is addressed by working with high-need school districts to develop lesson plans and demonstrations that encourage the gradual incorporation of mathematical tools in science classrooms. 

The technical challenges addressed in this work include accurately modeling the electronic structure of large, many-atom systems and developing a computationally efficient method to incorporate quantum dynamic effects in condensed-phase charge and energy transfer processes. The electronic structure challenge is addressed with fragment-based methods where a large system calculation is divided into many accurate calculations on smaller subsystems using a high level of theory. The challenge of dynamics is to develop a method that can accurately capture quantum effects, but that is based on classical molecular dynamics where the computational effort scales well with system size. Here, this is achieved by mapping the quantum dynamics of a complex system to the classical dynamics of an isomorphic classical system derived using the path-integral representation of quantum mechanics. The methods developed here are general, and allow accurate studies of quantum behavior in complex systems with applications to many areas beyond condensed-phase photochemistry. The group works with schools in New York State, and in particular the high-needs focus district of Syracuse City, to develop curricular
materials that incorporate math and that meet the new Next Generation Science Standards adopted by the state.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the detailed mechanism of light-driven chemical reactions is an important step towards the rational design of materials for use in organic electronic devices, molecular computing, and in several renewable energy technologies developed to harness solar power. While the development of ultrafast spectroscopic methods has revolutionized our ability to understand some aspects of these reactions, theoretical simulation methods are required to provide insights at the atomic and even electronic level.

This project focused on developing a theoretical method for simulation of light-driven processes where electronic and nuclear motion are coupled. Specifically, we leverage the quantum-classical isomorphism introduced in the path integral formulation of quantum mechanics to develop a classical molecular dynamics based method that captures quantum transitions. The use of classical dynamics gives these methods the ability to study high-dimensional systems that are out of reach to more traditional quantum mechanical approaches. Specific outcomes from this work include

(i) The development of Mapping Variable Ring Polymer Molecular Dynamics (MV-RPMD): a classical dynamics that captures coupled electron-nuclear motion.

(ii) Development of strategies to use MV-RPMD to describe photo-induced excited state dynamics where multiple excited states are coupled to each other

(iii) Mechanistic studies of proton-coupled electron transfer where 4 electron-proton states are coupled to nuclear vibrational modes. In particular, this study demonstrates that MV-RPMD can successfully identify pathways for proton and electron transfer in high dimensional systems

(iv) We have developed open-source software MAVARIC to implement MV-RPMD calculations in model systems to enable widespread adoption.

The second focus of this project was the study of Singlet Fission in organic photovoltaic materials. Singlet Fission is the process where the excited state formed upon photo-excitation in certain molecules can be shared with a neighboring molecule to form two lower-lying excited states that can be independently harvested at an interface to double the photon-electron conversion efficiency in solar devices. In this project, we established a novel mechanism for singlet fission, and we elucidated key design principles to enhance the rate of fission as well as to optimize visible absorption. Key results include

(i) Identifying key vibrational modes that drive Singlet Fission in covalently linked dimer systems and structural modifications that can impact their absorption of visible light

(ii) Developing strategies for excited state localization using high level electronic structure theory and comparing against more efficient, simpler methods that can be used for the study of larger molecules

The broader impacts aspects of this project focused on curricular advances at the undergraduate level to enhance and expand computer literacy among students in the Arts and Science college at Cornell. Several studies have demonstrated that making coding and computational techniques accessible to a broad audience can have significant impact in motivating the choice of a STEM career. Under the umbrella of this project, we have developed

(i) A "Coding for All" freshman course designed to introduce students to coding through the study of real-word scienctific problems. This strategy was deliberatly chosen based on studies that show that under-represented groups in STEM can be better motivated to learn skills based on the practical applications; we cover diverse topics including modeling the spread of infectious diseases, modeling airplane flight, genetics, and how enzymes work. This class has multiple unique features. First, coding is taught on a need-to-know basis where students learn the skills needed to solve a particular problem. Second, the classe emphasizes teach-by-learning: we work with the Ithaca Sciencenter collaboratively to develop a computational project, and our students spend time with middle and high-school students at the Sciencenter to help them develop code to solve a real-world problem.

(ii) A "Principles of Molecular Simulation" course: the creation of this course pre-dates the present project, but under this project we have significantly expanded the curriculum to focus on computational chemistry and to increase the interactive project-based component.

Taken together, both courses are designed to be part of a data science minor in the college of Arts and Science at Cornell.
